text:
Location: estados unidos 
Price range: technically unlimited but I'm naturally frugal 
Lease or buy: buy 
New/used: don't care but don't want a maintenance headache 
Type of vehicle: sedan? SUV? Prefer sedan. 
Must haves: 4 doors, not a project car, fast (wife wants 4 doors/no project car, I want fast)
Transmission: don't care, can drive manual 
Intended use: daily driver and child hauler 
Vehicles considered: charger scat pack, Tesla 3 
1st vehicle: not even close, I've had a ton of daily drivers and a few project/race cars over the years
Maintenance: Can do almost anything including engine rebuild and complete vehicle assembly but don't have time or workshop anymore. I'm going to be paying for oil changes.

Location: United States- Nationwide search
Price range: $7-15k
Lease or Buy: Buy
New or used: Used
Type of vehicle: Sedan, coupe, hatchback
Must haves: RWD/AWD only, some power (0-60 in 6ish or less), reliability
Desired transmission: MANUAL ONLY
Intended use: Daily driver
Vehicles you've already considered: 135i, 335i, mk1 TT, STIs, G37s, 
Is this your 1st vehicle: No
Do you need a Warranty: No
Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: Yes
Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: Some, but mostly no
Additional Notes: Looking for something affordable and quick to get once I graduate. Really only interested in manuals, winter friendly is a plus but not absolutely necessary.

Location: US
Price range: 50-80k
Lease or Buy: Either
New or used: Either
Type of vehicle: Truck/Car/SUV (Luxury/sport)
Must haves: 4x4, AWD, quiet cabin, good sound system, comfortable seats
Desired transmission (auto/manual, etc): Auto
Intended use: Daily driver mostly highway, some family use.
Vehicles you've already considered: F150 Tremor, BMW X5 45E, SQ5/S5, Macan S, GV70, Volvo XC60/90
Is this your 1st vehicle: No
Do you need a Warranty: Yes
Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: Very basic minor work
Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: With enough time, money and patience maybe
Additional Notes: Looking for a nice luxury/sports vehicle.  Needs to be good in the snow, has to have very nice seats and would prefer a quiet cabin with a nice audio system.  I'm not anti-ICE or EV, and am pretty much open to anything at this point.  I am coming from a 15 Murano so anything at this point will be a decent upgrade.

check out the volkswagen atlas crossport with the v6, the SEL R-line trim is the fanciest top of the line, they got a very good sound system and they sell for about 51k fully loaded, i work at a volkswagen dealership north of illinois and i love those things
Volkswagen atlas crossport SEL r-line

Location: USA - West coast 
Price range: cheapest that fits criteria, hopefully 50k or less
Lease or Buy: Buy
New or used: New
Type of vehicle: fully Electric
Must haves: Capacity to carry wood ('8 boards), including a sheet of plywood.
Desired transmission (auto/manual, etc): EV, so auto.
Intended use: Daily Driver
Vehicles you've already considered: f-150 lightning, but I really don't want a pickup that big. EV6, Ioniq 5, XC40.
Is this your 1st vehicle: no
Do you need a Warranty: preferable.
Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: yes
Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: no
Additional Notes: I don't like the size of modern pickups and SUV's in general, they are far too large for my preference. The Rivian r1T seems to me more my size of pickup, but the price of it makes it firmly outside my range.

I don't think there's an EV in your price range that can carry 8' plywood easily while being smaller than a full-size pickup. I'm not sure what to tell you. Maybe someone can correct me.
If you like the size of the EV6 and the Ioniq 5, regardless of their not-great ability to haul long things, they're both excellent vehicles and definitely high on my list of fairly affordable EVs. The Ford Mach E is also great -- you'd pay a bit more than the EV6 or Ioniq 5 for a Mach E with AWD and the extended range battery, but you get a better driving experience and a cool interior space. I like the Volvo XC40 Recharge in the luxury brands, as well as the Genesis GV70 and Cadillac Lyriq, but none of these are particularly large inside.

Yea, i was afraid of that answer. It seems like the only thing that really fits my needs at the moment is the lightning, and I really don't like it.   It kinda seems like right now all the new EV's are the same size and close in price.

Location: USA Massachusetts
Price range: 5-12k
Lease or Buy: Buy
New or used: Used
Type of vehicle: (Truck, Car, Sports Car, Sedan, Crossover, SUV, Racecar, Luxury etc.) Sporty Car, Sedan, Couple.
Must haves: (4x4, AWD, Fuel efficient, Navigation, Turbo, V8, V6, Trunk space, Smooth ride, Leather etc.) AWD
Desired transmission (auto/manual, etc): Manual
Intended use: (Daily Driver, Family Car, Weekend Car, Track Toy, Project Car, Work Truck, Off-roading etc.) Daily Driver
Vehicles you've already considered: WRX
Is this your 1st vehicle: Yes
Do you need a Warranty: It could be either
Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: (fluids, alternator, battery, brake pads etc)
Yes (my dad owns a auto body shop)
Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: (engine and transmission, timing belt/chains, body work, suspension etc ) Nah
Additional Notes:

Location: Lithuania
Price range: Up to 3500€
Lease or Buy: Buy
New or used: Used
Type of vehicle: Sedan/hatch (open to other suggestions)
Must haves: Fuel efficiency, minimal maintenance
Desired transmission (auto/manual, etc): Doesn't matter
Intended use: Daily city commuter
Vehicles you've already considered: VW Polo, Golf, Passat, Audi A3, A4, Toyota Yaris
Is this your 1st vehicle: Yes
Do you need a Warranty: No
Can you do Minor work on your vehicle: No
Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: No
Additional Notes: Preferred fuel is gasoline, performance is not a factor

Location: Northern MO
Lease/Buy: Buy.
New/Used: New if I can
Type: Camaro ZL1
Transmission: this is what I need help on.
First vehicle: no. I currently daily an '03 Honda pilot, but I've also driven a few other cars, mostly automatics though.
Considerations: I'm planning on getting a camaro zl1 before they die since it's been a dream car for years, I just don't know what transmission to try and get. The automatic comes with paddle shifters, so I'd still have control of gear changes if I go that route but actual manual is also kinda fun to do. My problem is I'd likely end up using this as my new daily and I have some serious adhd problems, so I'm not sure if being forced to change my gears every time I drive is gonna be a good option. And on top of that, I've driven a grand total of 2 manual cars, and both have been below 400hp, so jumping to 650 may be a little much but I'm not sure. Anyone with any experience, I'd love to hear your experience and thoughts to help me come to a decision.
